▿ Step
  ResponseEnded

▿ Request
  GET http://localhost:8080/home

▿ Response
  Status 200 OK
  Content-Length: 44816
  Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf8

id="hero"></a></div><div class=" col"><div><a href="#" class="btn medium h5 m-pl2 m-pr2 m-pt1 m-pb1 pf-link-white rounded bg-purple">Subscribe</a></div></div></div><div class="top-xs between-xs row"><div class="m-pt4 col col-xs-5" style="line-height:0"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64, " alt="" width="100%"></div><div class="z1 col col-xs-2"><div class="center body-leading fg-black regular lh-4" style="margin-right:-6rem;margin-left:-6rem">A new weekly Swift video series exploring functional programming and more.</div></div><div class="m-pt4 col col-xs-5" style="line-height:0"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64, " alt="" width="100%"></div></div><hr class="pf-divider border-top m-ml0 m-mr0 m-mt0 m-mb0 bg-white"><div class=" row"><div class=" col col-xs-7"><div class="m-pl3 m-pr3 m-pt3 m-pb3 d-pl4 d-pr4 d-pt4 d-pb4 bg-white"><strong class="h6 caps lh-4">Episode 4</strong><h1 class="h4 m-mt0"><a href="/episodes/ep4-type-safe-html-in-swift">Type-Safe HTML in Swift</a></h1><p class="fg-black regular h5 lh-4">As server-side Swift becomes more popular and widely adopted, it will be important to re-examine some of the past “best-practices” of web frameworks to see how Swift’s type system can improve upon them.</p><div class="m-mt2"><a href="/episodes/ep4-type-safe-html-in-swift" class="align-middle pf-link-purple fg-black regular h5 lh-4">Watch episode<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64, " alt="" class="align-middle m-ml1" width="16" height="16"></a></div></div></div><div class=" col col-xs-5"><div style="line-height:0"><a href="/episodes/ep4-type-safe-html-in-swift"><img src="https://waltpaper.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/6c7b04501f6e98ab94982a2743ede747-1024x768.jpeg" alt="" style="object-fit:contain;width:100%;height:100%"></a></div></div></div><hr class="pf-divider border-top m-ml0 m-mr0 m-mt0 m-mb0 bg-white"><div class=" row"><div class=" col col-xs-7"><div class="m-pl3 m-pr3 m-pt3 m-pb3 d-pl4 d-pr4 d-pt4 d-pb4 bg-white"><strong class="h6 caps lh-4">Episode 2</strong><h1 class="h4 m-mt0"><a href="/episodes/ep2-algebraic-structure-and-protocols">Algebraic Structure and Protocols</a></h1><p class="fg-black regular h5 lh-4">Protocols in Swift allow us to abstractly work with types that we know very little about. We distill the smallest piece of an interface that we want a type to conform to, and then we can write functions that are highly reusable. Mathematicians do something very similar to study objects abstractly, and it forms the field known as algebra. In this article we will link these two worlds together, and show that there is a fundamental piece missing when we only look at the protocol level.</p><div class="m-mt2"><a href="/episodes/ep2-algebraic-structure-and-protocols" class="align-middle pf-link-purple fg-black regular h5 lh-4">Watch episode<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64, " alt="" class="align-middle m-ml1" width="16" height="16"></a></div></div></div><div class=" col col-xs-5"><div style="line-height:0"><a href="/episodes/ep2-algebraic-structure-and-protocols"><img src="https://waltpaper.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/6c7b04501f6e98ab94982a2743ede747-1024x768.jpeg" alt="" style="object-fit:contain;width:100%;height:100%"></a></div></div></div><hr class="pf-divider border-top m-ml0 m-mr0 m-mt0 m-mb0 bg-white"><div class=" row"><div class=" col col-xs-7"><div class="m-pl3 m-pr3 m-pt3 m-pb3 d-pl4 d-pr4 d-pt4 d-pb4 bg-white"><strong class="h6 caps lh-4">Episode 3</strong><h1 class="h4 m-mt0"><a href="/episodes/ep3-the-algebra-of-predicates-and-sorting-functions">The Algebra of Predicates and Sorting Functions</a></h1><p class="fg-black regular h5 lh-4">We formulate predicates and sorting functions in terms of monoids and show how they can lead to very composable constructions.</p><div class="m-mt2"><a href="/episodes/ep3-the-algebra-of-predicates-and-sorting-functions" class="align-middle pf-link-purple fg-black regular h5 lh-4">Watch episode<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64, " alt="" class="align-middle m-ml1" width="16" height="16"></a></div></div></div><div class=" col col-xs-5"><div style="line-height:0"><a href="/episodes/ep3-the-algebra-of-predicates-and-sorting-functions"><img src="https://waltpaper.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/6c7b04501f6e98ab94982a2743ede747-1024x768.jpeg" alt="" style="object-fit:contain;width:100%;height:100%"></a></div></div></div><hr class="pf-divider border-top m-ml0 m-mr0 m-mt0 m-mb0 bg-white"><div class=" row"><div class=" col col-xs-7"><div class="m-pl3 m-pr3 m-pt3 m-pb3 d-pl4 d-pr4 d-pt4 d-pb4 bg-white"><strong class="h6 caps lh-4">Episode 1</strong><h1 class="h4 m-mt0"><a href="/episodes/ep1-proof-in-functions">Proof in Functions</a></h1><p class="fg-black regular h5 lh-4">Swift’s generic functions allow us to explore a beautiful idea that straddles the line between mathematics and computer science</p><div class="m-mt2"><a href="/episodes/ep1-proof-in-functions" class="align-middle pf-link-purple fg-black regular h5 lh-4">Watch episode<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64, " alt="" class="align-middle m-ml1" width="16" height="16"></a></div></div></div><div class=" col col-xs-5"><div style="line-height:0"><a href="/episodes/ep1-proof-in-functions"><img src="https://waltpaper.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/6c7b04501f6e98ab94982a2743ede747-1024x768.jpeg" alt="" style="object-fit:contain;width:100%;height:100%"></a></div></div></div><footer class="row m-pl4 m-pr4 m-pt4 m-pb4 border-top bg-white" style="border-top-color:#ccc"><div class=" col col-xs-12 col-md-6"><div class="m-pr4"><h4 class="h4 m-mb0"><a href="/home">Point-Free</a></h4><p>A weekly video series on functional programming and the Swift programming language. Hosted by <a href="https://www.twitter.com/mbrandonw" class="text-decoration-none">Brandon Williams</a> and <a href="https://www.twitter.com/stephencelis" class="text-decoration-none">Stephen Celis</a>.</p></div></div><div class=" col col-xs-4 col-md-2"><div><h5 class="h5">Account</h5><ol class="list-reset"><li><a href="#">Subscribe</a></li><li><a href="/pricing">Pricing</a></li></ol></div></div><div class=" col col-xs-4 col-md-2"><div><h5 class="h5">Content</h5><ol class="list-reset"><li><a href="/home">Videos</a></li><li><a href="http://www.fewbutripe.com">Few, but ripe…</a></li><li><a href="http://www.stephencelis.com">Stephen Celis</a></li></ol></div></div><div class=" col col-xs-4 col-md-2"><div><h5 class="h5">More</h5><ol class="list-reset"><li><a href="https://www.twitter.com/pointfreeco">Twitter</a></li><li><a href="https://www.github.com/pointfreeco">GitHub</a></li><li><a href="mailto:support@pointfree.co">Contact us</a></li></ol></div></div><div class=" col col-xs-12"><p class="fg-gray400 center h6 m-pt2">The content of this site is license under <a href="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/4.0/">CC BY-NC-SA 4.0</a>, and the underlying <a href="https://www.github.com/pointfreeco/pointfreeco">source code</a> to run this site is licensed under the <a href="https://www.github.com/pointfreeco/pointfreeco/blob/master/LICENSE">MIT license</a>.
